'kaxil', 'id': 8811558, 'node_id': 'MDQ6VXNlcjg4MTE1NTg=', 'avatar_url': 'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/8811558?v=4', 'gravatar_id': '', 'url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/kaxil', 'followers_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/followers', 'following_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/gists{/gist_id}', 'starred_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'subscriptions_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'user_view_type': 'public', 'site_admin': False}, 'name': 'boring-cyborg', 'description': 'A Github bot to automatically label PRs, issues and perform all the boring operations that you don\'t want to do.\r\n\r\n\r\n![Using Boring Cyborg Probot to add new labels](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/master/assets/usage-screenshot-1.png)\r\n\r\n![Congratulate user on first merged PR](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/master/assets/usage-first-merged-pr.gif)\r\n\r\n## Features\r\n\r\n* Add labels based on the path of the file that are modified in the PR.\r\n* Welcome new users to your project when they open their first Issue/PR or first merged PR by an\r\nautomated comment. \r\n* Insert Issue (Jira/Github etc) link in PR description based on the Issue ID in PR title.\r\n* Verifies if commits/PR titles match the regular expression specified\r\n* Check if a branch is up to date with the master when specific files are modified in the PR. This is helpful when you desire the changes to be applied sequentially, for example, alembic migrations.\r\n\r\n## Usage\r\n\r\n1. **[Configure the Github App](https://github.com/apps/boring-cyborg)**\r\n2. After installing the Github app, create `.github/boring-cyborg.yml` in the default branch to enable it\r\n3. It will start scanning for pull requests within few minutes.\r\n\r\n```yaml\r\n##### Labeler ##########################################################################################################\r\n# Enable "labeler" for your PR that would add labels to PRs based on the paths that are modified in the PR.\r\nlabelPRBasedOnFilePath:\r\n  # Add \'label1\' to any changes within \'example\' folder or any subfolders\r\n  label1:\r\n    - example/**/*\r\n\r\n  # Add \'label2\' to any file changes within \'example2\' folder\r\n  label2:\r\n    - example2/*\r\n\r\n  # Complex: Add \'area/core\' label to any change within the \'core\' package\r\n  area/core:\r\n    - src/core/*\r\n    - src/core/**/*  \r\n\r\n  # Add \'test\' label to any change to *.spec.js files within the source dir\r\n  test:\r\n    - src/**/*.spec.js\r\n\r\n##### Greetings ########################################################################################################\r\n# Comment to be posted to welcome users when they open their first PR\r\nfirstPRWelcomeComment: >\r\n  Thanks for opening this pull request! Please check out our contributing guidelines.\r\n\r\n# Comment to be posted to congratulate user on their first merged PR\r\nfirstPRMergeComment: >\r\n  Awesome work, congrats on your first merged pull request!\r\n\r\n# Comment to be posted to on first time issues\r\nfirstIssueWelcomeComment: >\r\n  Thanks for opening your first issue here! Be sure to follow the issue template!\r\n\r\n###### IssueLink Adder #################################################################################################\r\n# Insert Issue (Jira/Github etc) link in PR description based on the Issue ID in PR title.\r\ninsertIssueLinkInPrDescription:\r\n   # specify the placeholder for the issue link that should be present in the description\r\n  descriptionIssuePlaceholderRegexp: "^Issue link: (.*)$"\r\n  matchers:\r\n    # you can have several matches - for different types of issues\r\n    # only the first matching entry is replaced\r\n    jiraIssueMatch:\r\n      # specify the regexp of issue id that you can find in the title of the PR\r\n      # the match groups can be used to build the issue id (${1}, ${2}, etc.).\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4})\\]\r\n      # the issue link to be added. ${1}, ${2} ... are replaced with the match groups from the\r\n      # title match (remember to use quotes)\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "[${1}](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/${1}/)"\r\n    docOnlyIssueMatch:\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-X{4})\\]\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "`Document only change, no JIRA issue`"\r\n\r\n###### Title Validator #################################################################################################\r\n# Verifies if commit/PR titles match the regexp specified\r\nverifyTitles:\r\n  # Regular expression that should be matched by titles of commits or PR\r\n  titleRegexp: ^\\[AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4}\\].*$|^\\[AIRFLOW-XXXX\\].*$\r\n  # If set to true, it will always check the PR title (as opposed to the individual commits).\r\n  alwaysUsePrTitle: true\r\n  # If set to true, it will only check the commit in case there is a single commit.\r\n  # In case of multiple commits it will check PR title.\r\n  # This reflects the standard behaviour of Github that for `Squash & Merge` GitHub\r\n  # uses the PR title rather than commit messages for the squashed commit ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯\r\n  # For single-commit PRs it takes the squashed commit message from the commit as expected.\r\n  #\r\n  # If set to false it will check all commit messages. This is useful when you do not squash commits at merge.\r\n  validateEitherPrOrSingleCommitTitle: true\r\n  # The title the GitHub status should appear from.\r\n  statusTitle: "Title Validator"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title passes validation.\r\n  successMessage: "Validation successful!"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title fails validation.\r\n  # Allows insertion of ${type} (commit/PR), ${title} (the title validated) and ${regex} (the titleRegexp above).\r\n  failureMessage: "Wrong ${type} title: ${title}"\r\n\r\n###### PR/Branch Up-To-Date Checker ####################################################################################\r\n# Check if the branch is up to date with master when certain files are modified\r\ncheckUpToDate:\r\n  # The default branch is "master", change the branch if you want to check against a different target branch  \r\n  targetBranch: master\r\n  files:\r\n  # File paths that you want to check for\r\n  # In this example, it checks if the branch is up to date when alembic migrations are modified in the PR.\r\n  # It helps avoid multiple heads in alembic migrations in a collaborative development project.\r\n    - airflow/migrations/*\r\n    - airflow/migrations/**/*\r\n    - airflow/alembic.ini\r\n```\r\n\r\nAll the features are optional. Simply add the config for the feature you want to use.\r\n\r\nIf you are having issues with the GitHub app not working, please create an issue on https://github.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/issues.\r\n\r\n', 'external_url': 'https://github.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/apps/boring-cyborg', 'created_at': '2020-01-04T23:52:58Z', 'updated_at': '2020-03-13T21:08:37Z', 'permissions': {'checks': 'write', 'issues': 'write', 'metadata': 'read', 'pull_requests': 'write', 'single_file': 'read', 'statuses': 'write'}, 'events': ['issues', 'label', 'pull_request', 'pull_request_review', 'pull_request_review_comment']}}]

to the general capabilities of the infrastructure and should not be customized by users. Administrator can use tools like [gatekeeper](https://github.com/open-policy-agent/gatekeeper) to inject more custom features.\r\n\r\nyou are generally rigth... but there are complex situation (like a bank) where hundreds of different applications will have to share the same cluster, and those cases are not manageable with an aproach "one size fits all"... they give some guidelines and let developers sort out.\r\n\r\nIn my case, we use a DB (provided by the cloud vendor) that is connectable only via sidecar container (that work as a proxy), while another sidecar container keeps some general settings. My sidecar containers are "always on", but since the kubernetes job ends when all "main" containers are done... we have a case of "main + sidecar".\r\n\r\nAt the moment, we are evaluating dolphin; if we\'ll decide to continue, I\'ll probably implement a variation of the current kubernetes task (maybe in the GUI we can add a selector "adavanced mode" and a wide textbox, to let the user write his own YAML file... something similar to what you did in the "cluster configuration" part).\r\nOf course, if you guide me enough, the outcome can be something solid and good enough to be pulled in your the same cluster, and those cases are not manageable with an aproach "one size fits all"... they give some guidelines and let developers sort out.\r\n> \r\n> In my case, we use a DB (provided by the cloud vendor) that is connectable only via sidecar container (that work as a proxy), while another sidecar container keeps some general settings. My sidecar containers are "always on", but since the kubernetes job ends when all "main" containers are done... we have a case of "main + sidecar".\r\n> \r\n> At the moment, we are evaluating dolphin; if we\'ll decide to continue, I\'ll probably implement a variation of the current kubernetes task (maybe in the GUI we can add a selector "adavanced mode" and a wide textbox, to let the user write his own YAML file... something similar to what you did in the "cluster configuration" part). Of course, if you guide me enough, the outcome can be something solid and good enough to be pulled in your main repository...\r\n\r\n@giovannidalloglio \r\nFirst, I believe that this scenario makes sense and is a beneficial feature for the K8S task.  However, allowing users to write the entire YAML file of a `Job` can introduce issues such as security risks and excessive flexibility, which can require a lot of work.\r\n\r\nTherefore, I propose to provide an advanced mode that allows users to write only the [initContainer](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/pods/sidecar-containers/#jobs-with-sidecar-containers) sections.  This is a balanced approach.  This change does not greatly affect security. It\'s just a small number of changes.\r\n\r\nHowever, I still have a question: does storage need to be shared between containers, i.e., do we need to mount volumes?\r\n\r\ncc: @SbloodyS @EricGao888 'site_admin': False}, 'created_at': '2024-09-29T03:43:51Z', 'updated_at': '2024-09-29T03:47:28Z', 'author_association': 'MEMBER', 'body': "Please provide the needed information of a DSIP https://github.com/apache/dolphinscheduler/issues/14102.\r\n\r\n> The purpose of SDK is to allow third-party systems to register in DS through the integration of DS SDK plugins. The SDK includes third-party system registration, task list functions, task parameter functions, and task execution functions. Third party systems can delegate tasks to DS triggers by integrating SDKs and corresponding implementations. For example, in a data quality system, if a company wants to use its own data quality system to implement data quality audit tasks, and the data processing tasks are in DS, the processing tasks of the two platforms cannot be triggered by dependencies. The purpose of this feature is to solve the integration problem between DS and third-party systems. The above introduction is about the modification of DS, including the main process of task definition development and task execution. The main implementation of this DSIP is to provide a dependency (DS SDK) for third-party systems; 2. Add a new node (Other System node) to DS\r\n\r\nLet's ignore whether this feature make sense or not. I didn't see any detail information about this DSIP.\r\n\r\nI have ever implemented a similar system, I am sure you are not aware of the key issue here.\r\n\r\nHave you considar the sdk dependency? register in DS through the integration of DS SDK plugins. The SDK includes third-party system registration, task list functions, task parameter functions, and task execution functions. Third party systems can delegate tasks to DS triggers by integrating SDKs and corresponding implementations. For example, in a data quality system, if a company wants to use its own data quality system to implement data quality audit tasks, and the data processing tasks are in DS, the processing tasks of the two platforms cannot be triggered by dependencies. The purpose of this feature is to solve the integration problem between DS and third-party systems. The above introduction is about the modification of DS, including the main process of task definition development and task execution. The main implementation of this DSIP is to provide a dependency (DS SDK) for third-party systems; 2. Please provide detailed information about DSIP in the email. If there are any unclear descriptions, they will be added to the issue.\r\n3. The dependency of SDK is necessary for third-party systems to delegate tasks to DS triggering, and it does not have too much intrusion on third-party systems. Third party systems need to implement three functions, among which the task execution function should have already been implemented.\r\n4. The Netty communication built into the SDK synchronizes the IP and port of third-party systems to DS during the system registration (service startup) phase. Currently, the first version does not consider load balancing functionality, although it allows the same third-party system to register multiple services.\r\nWhen creating the Other System node of DS, users need to select the identifier of the third-party system. The master then retrieves the registration information of the third-party system from the database based on the identifier, and communicates with the third-party system to execute the corresponding function.\r\n6. The first version did not implement log collection function. In the future, log viewing function will be added, and logs will be retained locally in third-party systems. When querying the page, the SDK package will be called to obtain the corresponding file content (during this process, the log storage directory is saved in DS, and the log file reading process will not execute the file)\r\n7. The first version did not implement load balancing provided by third-party systems, but when instance communication fails, it will communicate with other instances. The follow-up plan is to add third-party system resource monitoring function, which will mark the available and unavailable status of the system during the monitoring process.\r\n8. The entire process is a call from DS to the third-party system, with only two stages of registration and task execution status synchronization. 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/subscriptions', 'organizations_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/orgs', 'repos_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/repos', 'events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/events{/privacy}', 'received_events_url': 'https://api.github.com/users/kaxil/received_events', 'type': 'User', 'user_view_type': 'public', 'site_admin': False}, 'name': 'boring-cyborg', 'description': 'A Github bot to automatically label PRs, issues and perform all the boring operations that you don\'t want to do.\r\n\r\n\r\n![Using Boring Cyborg Probot to add new labels](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/master/assets/usage-screenshot-1.png)\r\n\r\n![Congratulate user on first merged PR](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/master/assets/usage-first-merged-pr.gif)\r\n\r\n## Features\r\n\r\n* Add labels based on the path of the file that are modified in the PR.\r\n* Welcome new users to your project when they open their first Issue/PR or first merged PR by an\r\nautomated comment. \r\n* Insert Issue (Jira/Github etc) link in PR description based on the Issue ID in PR title.\r\n* Verifies if commits/PR titles match the regular expression specified\r\n* Check if a branch is up to date with the master when specific files are modified in the PR. This is helpful when you desire the changes to be applied sequentially, for example, alembic migrations.\r\n\r\n## Usage\r\n\r\n1. **[Configure the Github App](https://github.com/apps/boring-cyborg)**\r\n2. After installing the Github app, create `.github/boring-cyborg.yml` in the default branch to enable it\r\n3. It will start scanning for pull requests within few minutes.\r\n\r\n```yaml\r\n##### Labeler ##########################################################################################################\r\n# Enable "labeler" for your PR that would add labels to PRs based on the paths that are modified in the PR.\r\nlabelPRBasedOnFilePath:\r\n  # Add \'label1\' to any changes within \'example\' folder or any subfolders\r\n  label1:\r\n    - example/**/*\r\n\r\n  # Add \'label2\' to any file changes within \'example2\' folder\r\n  label2:\r\n    - example2/*\r\n\r\n  # Complex: Add \'area/core\' label to any change within the \'core\' package\r\n  area/core:\r\n    - src/core/*\r\n    - src/core/**/*  \r\n\r\n  # Add \'test\' label to any change to *.spec.js files within the source dir\r\n  test:\r\n    - src/**/*.spec.js\r\n\r\n##### Greetings ########################################################################################################\r\n# Comment to be posted to welcome users when they open their first PR\r\nfirstPRWelcomeComment: >\r\n  Thanks for opening this pull request! Please check out our contributing guidelines.\r\n\r\n# Comment to be posted to congratulate user on their first merged PR\r\nfirstPRMergeComment: >\r\n  Awesome work, congrats on your first merged pull request!\r\n\r\n# Comment to be posted to on first time issues\r\nfirstIssueWelcomeComment: >\r\n  Thanks for opening your first issue here! Be sure to follow the issue template!\r\n\r\n###### IssueLink Adder #################################################################################################\r\n# Insert Issue (Jira/Github etc) link in PR description based on the Issue ID in PR title.\r\ninsertIssueLinkInPrDescription:\r\n   # specify the placeholder for the issue link that should be present in the description\r\n  descriptionIssuePlaceholderRegexp: "^Issue link: (.*)$"\r\n  matchers:\r\n    # you can have several matches - for different types of issues\r\n    # only the first matching entry is replaced\r\n    jiraIssueMatch:\r\n      # specify the regexp of issue id that you can find in the title of the PR\r\n      # the match groups can be used to build the issue id (${1}, ${2}, etc.).\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4})\\]\r\n      # the issue link to be added. ${1}, ${2} ... are replaced with the match groups from the\r\n      # title match (remember to use quotes)\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "[${1}](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/${1}/)"\r\n    docOnlyIssueMatch:\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-X{4})\\]\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "`Document only change, no JIRA issue`"\r\n\r\n###### Title Validator #################################################################################################\r\n# Verifies if commit/PR titles match the regexp specified\r\nverifyTitles:\r\n  # Regular expression that should be matched by titles of commits or PR\r\n  titleRegexp: ^\\[AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4}\\].*$|^\\[AIRFLOW-XXXX\\].*$\r\n  # If set to true, it will always check the PR title (as opposed to the individual commits).\r\n  alwaysUsePrTitle: true\r\n  # If set to true, it will only check the commit in case there is a single commit.\r\n  # In case of multiple commits it will check PR title.\r\n  # This reflects the standard behaviour of Github that for `Squash & Merge` GitHub\r\n  # uses the PR title rather than commit messages for the squashed commit ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯\r\n  # For single-commit PRs it takes the squashed commit message from the commit as expected.\r\n  #\r\n  # If set to false it will check all commit messages. This is useful when you do not squash commits at merge.\r\n  validateEitherPrOrSingleCommitTitle: true\r\n  # The title the GitHub status should appear from.\r\n  statusTitle: "Title Validator"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title passes validation.\r\n  successMessage: "Validation successful!"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title fails validation.\r\n  # Allows insertion of ${type} (commit/PR), ${title} (the title validated) and ${regex} (the titleRegexp above).\r\n  failureMessage: "Wrong ${type} title: ${title}"\r\n\r\n###### PR/Branch Up-To-Date Checker ####################################################################################\r\n# Check if the branch is up to date with master when certain files are modified\r\ncheckUpToDate:\r\n  # The default branch is "master", change the branch if you want to check against a different target branch  \r\n  targetBranch: master\r\n  files:\r\n  # File paths that you want to check for\r\n  # In this example, it checks if the branch is up to date when alembic migrations are modified in the PR.\r\n  # It helps avoid multiple heads in alembic migrations in a collaborative development project.\r\n    - airflow/migrations/*\r\n    - airflow/migrations/**/*\r\n    - airflow/alembic.ini\r\n```\r\n\r\nAll the features are optional. Simply add the config for the feature you want to use.\r\n\r\nIf you are having issues with the GitHub app not working, please create an issue on https://github.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg/issues.\r\n\r\n', 'external_url': 'https://github.com/kaxil/boring-cyborg', 'html_url': 'https://github.com/apps/boring-cyborg', 'created_at': '2020-01-04T23:52:58Z', 'updated_at': '2020-03-13T21:08:37Z', 'permissions': {'checks': 'write', 'issues': 'write', 'metadata': 'read', 'pull_requests': 'write', 'single_file': 'read', 'statuses': 'write'}, 'events': ['issues', 'label', 'pull_request', 'pull_request_review', 'pull_request_review_comment']}}]

for different types of issues\r\n    # only the first matching entry is replaced\r\n    jiraIssueMatch:\r\n      # specify the regexp of issue id that you can find in the title of the PR\r\n      # the match groups can be used to build the issue id (${1}, ${2}, etc.).\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4})\\]\r\n      # the issue link to be added. ${1}, ${2} ... are replaced with the match groups from the\r\n      # title match (remember to use quotes)\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "[${1}](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/${1}/)"\r\n    docOnlyIssueMatch:\r\n      titleIssueIdRegexp: \\[(AIRFLOW-X{4})\\]\r\n      descriptionIssueLink: "`Document only change, no JIRA issue`"\r\n\r\n###### Title Validator #################################################################################################\r\n# Verifies if commit/PR titles match the regexp specified\r\nverifyTitles:\r\n  # Regular expression that should be matched by titles of commits or PR\r\n  titleRegexp: ^\\[AIRFLOW-[0-9]{4}\\].*$|^\\[AIRFLOW-XXXX\\].*$\r\n  # If set to true, it will always check the PR title (as opposed to the individual commits).\r\n  alwaysUsePrTitle: true\r\n  # If set to true, it will only check the commit in case there is a single commit.\r\n  # In case of multiple commits it will check PR title.\r\n  # This reflects the standard behaviour of Github that for `Squash & Merge` GitHub\r\n  # uses the PR title rather than commit messages for the squashed commit ¯\\_(ツ)_/¯\r\n  # For single-commit PRs it takes the squashed commit message from the commit as expected.\r\n  #\r\n  # If set to false it will check all commit messages. This is useful when you do not squash commits at merge.\r\n  validateEitherPrOrSingleCommitTitle: true\r\n  # The title the GitHub status should appear from.\r\n  statusTitle: "Title Validator"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title passes validation.\r\n  successMessage: "Validation successful!"\r\n  # A custom message to be displayed when the title fails validation.\r\n  # Allows insertion of ${type} (commit/PR), ${title} (the title validated) and ${regex} (the titleRegexp above).\r\n  failureMessage: "Wrong ${type} title: ${title}"\r\n\r\n###### PR/Branch Up-To-Date Checker ####################################################################################\r\n# Check if the branch is up to date with master when certain files are modified\r\ncheckUpToDate:\r\n  # The default branch is "master", change the branch if you want to check against a different target branch  \r\n  targetBranch: master\r\n  files:\r\n  # File paths that you want to check for\r\n  # In this example, it checks if the branch is up to date when alembic migrations are modified in the PR.\r\n  # It helps avoid multiple heads in alembic migrations in a collaborative development project.\r\n    - airflow/migrations/*\r\n    - airflow/migrations/**/*\r\n    - airflow/alembic.ini\r\n```\r\n\r\nAll the features are optional.
